The following antibodies were used for immunoprecipitation: 3 μl of anti-HA 1The abbreviations used are: HA, hemagglutinin; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation; IP, immunoprecipitation; Ab, antibody; WT, wild type; GFP, green fluorescent protein. antibody (number 1666606, Roche) per ChIP; 2 μl of anti-mono-Me Lys-4, -di-Me Lys-4, and -tri-Me Lys-4 antibody (abCam); 50 μl of Sir3 monoclonal antibody (D. Gottschiling); 3 μl of Pan-anti-acetyl H4 antibody (B. Turner), and 3 μl of anti-acetylated Lys-9/H3 Lys-14 antibody (Upstate). Standard PCR analysis (30–33 cycles) was done on 1:10, 1:20, and 1:50 dilutions of the input, antibody-precipitated DNA, and control without antibody. Real time PCR analysis was performed on an ABI Prism 7000 (ABI) using Sybr Green. A standard curve of WT yeast genomic DNA diluted 1:10, 1:20, 1:100, 1:1000, and 1:10,000 was done for each amplicon. Amplification within the linear range was obtained with the input chromatin diluted 1:30 and IPs diluted 1:2 (anti-HA and mono-Me Lys-4 antibodies), 1:100 (anti-di-Me and -tri-Me Lys-4 antibodies), and 1:20 (anti-Rap1 and anti-acetyl H3 and H4 antibodies). Control IPs were done with anti-HA antibody from the untagged strain. PCR was done in triplicate and the experiments were repeated in two different strains. After each run, a melting curve was performed to ensure that no primer dimers contaminated the quantification and that the product had the expected melting temperature. Samples were also subjected to agarose gel electrophoresis to confirm the integrity of the product. A signal was calculated from the average of at least three dilutions of IP, control IP (no antibody), or input and then corrected for the dilution factor when the appropriate dilutions showed a linear relationship and the PCR reaction was exponential. Relative fluorescent intensities are calculated as follows: ((ΣIP signals/ΣIP samples) or (Σno Ab signals/Σno Ab samples))/(Σinput signals/Σinput samples), where Σ is signals and Ab is antibody. The variability was less than 10% of the value shown between the different immunoprecipitations. The primers used for PCR analysis are available on request. Western Blot—Western blot of total yeast extracts was performed using standard procedures. The membranes were blocked for 3 h in Tris-buffered saline, 7% Tween 20, 5% bovine serum albumin at room temperature. The antibodies (diluted 1:1000, ≅4 °C) used were: anti-Sir2 (sc-6667, Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.), anti-Sir4 (sc-6671, Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.), anti-Rap1 (S. Schawalder), anti-HA (number 1666606, Roche), anti-Tub1 (Ab 6161, AbCam), and anti-Dot1 (Ab 4164, AbCam). In Vitro Binding—To monitor the binding of Sir3p to the H3 amino-terminal tail, we synthesized peptides corresponding to amino acids 1–16 of H3, either unmodified or trimethylated at Lys-4. The peptides contained a single cysteine residue at the COOH terminus. The carboxyl-terminal half of Sir3p (amino acids 510–970) was expressed in bacteria as a glutathione S-transferase fusion and purified on reduced glutathione-Sepharose beads. The fusion protein was eluted from the bead and dialyzed against 10 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 3 mm EDTA, and 0.005% v/v surfactant P20 (buffer X). The H3 NH2-terminal peptides were cross-linked via their COOH-terminal Cys residue, using standard electronic data capture/NHS technology, to the interaction surface of carboxymethyl dextran cells (Affinity Sensors, Cambridge, UK). The cells were then placed in an IASYS Plus surface plasmon resonance instrument, and interactions with Sir3p were monitored under standard conditions in buffer X. The Set1p Methyltransferase Activity Is Necessary for Silencing at Telomeres and HML but Not at the HMR Locus—We have previously reported that Set1p activity is necessary for the optimal transcription of many genes in S. cerevisiae. To analyze the role of lysine 4 (Lys-4) H3 methylation in silencing, we used the set1C1068A point mutant. This mutant associates with the Set1p complex, but it is catalytically inactive for H3 Lys-4 mono-, di-, and trimethyltransferase activities (16Santos-Rosa H. Schneider R. Bernstein B.E. Karabetsou N. Morillon A. Weise C. Schreiber S.L. Mellor J. Kouzarides T. Mol. Cell. 2003; 12: 1325-1332Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar). Isogenic WT and set1C1068A strains carry a URA3 reporter at the naturally occurring locus (euchromatic site). At telomere 07-L, HML and HMR loci (heterochromatic sites) were tested for silencing by their ability to grow in fluoro-orotic acid-containing plates. Fig. 1A shows that mutation of SET1 causes loss of silencing at the telomere of chromosome VII and HML. This result corroborates data found with the set1α strain (17Nislow C. Ray E. Pillus L. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 2421-2436Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar, 18Krogan N.J. Dover J. Khorrami S. Greenblatt J.F. Schneider J. Johnston M. Shilatifard A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 10753-10755Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar). Interestingly, silencing at the HMR locus is not affected by mutation of SET1. The different behavior of the HML and HMR alleles regarding silencing has also been reported in relation to other locus-specific regulators (22Ehrenhofer-Murray A.E. Rivier D.H. Rine J. Genetics. 1997; 145: 923-934Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 23Xu E.Y. Kim S. Rivier D.H. Genetics. 1999; 153: 25-33PubMed Google Scholar). Heterochromatic Sites Are Hypomodified for H3 Lys-4 Mono-, Di-, and Trimethylation—To understand how Set1p contributes to silencing, we monitored the H3 Lys-4 methylation state of the reporter URA3 gene located at euchromatic and heterochromatic sites (euchromatic-ChrV, telomere 07-L, and HML and HMR loci). The pattern of mono-, di-, and trimethylation of H3 Lys-4 found on the inactive and active URA3 gene (Fig. 1B, left and right panels, respectively) revealed that only the euchromatic site is hypermethylated (relative fluorescence units above 1.0). All heterochromatic sites studied were hypomethylated. The level of methylation was inversely correlated to the strength of silencing, suggesting that the presence of H3 Lys-4 methylation in heterochromatin is not required for gene silencing. To further analyze this, the H3 Lys-4 methylation levels at several nucleosomes from 5′ (nucleosome +1) to 3′ (nucleosome +6) of the URA3 gene were determined (Fig. 1C). No methylation was found at the heterochromatic HMLα-E site, in contrast to the characteristic accumulation of methylated H3 Lys-4 at the 5′ end of the euchromatic URA3 gene (Fig. 1C) (24Ng H.H. Robert F. Young R.A. Struhl K. Mol. Cell. 2003; 11: 709-719Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (857) Google Scholar). These results indicate that silencing in heterochromatin is not a result of Set1p activity on the silent sites. Because Set1p activates transcription of many genes, we tested whether the defect in silencing in the set1C1068A strain was due to a general decrease in the levels of silencing proteins. As shown in Fig. 1D, the levels of Rap1, Sir2p, Sir4p, and HA-Sir3p were equivalent in total extracts of SET1 and isogenic set1C1068A strains. Thus, Set1p does not contribute to silencing by regulating the expression of the main silencing factors. Mutation of SET1 Affects the Sir3p Occupancy at Several Heterochromatic Sites—It has been reported that mutations in the histone-modifying enzymes responsible for acetylation of H3 and H4, as well as methylation of H3 Lys-79, affect silencing by decreasing the amount of Sir proteins at the heterochromatic sites (10Kristjuhan A. Wittschieben B.O. Walker J. Roberts D. Cairns B.R. Svejstrup J.Q. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 7551-7556Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 20Ng H.H. Dole S. Struhl K. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 33625-33628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar, 21Van Leeuwen F. Gafken P.R. Gottschling D.E. Cell. 2002; 109: 745-756Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (674) Google Scholar). The current model is that hyperacetylated H3 and H4 (in particular H4 Lys-16) and hypermethylated H3 Lys-79 create a suboptimal environment for the Sir3 and Sir4 proteins to spread. The silencing factors are therefore restricted to heterochromatic areas, which are hypoacetylated and hypomethylated at Lys-79. We sought to determine whether this is the case for H3 Lys-4 methylation. Sir3p was analyzed because it is necessary for the spreading of silencing via direct interaction with the amino-terminal tails of histones H3 and H4 (4Hecht A. Laroche T. Strahl-Bolsinger S. Gasser S.M. Grunstein M. Cell. 1995; 80: 583-592Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (697) Google Scholar). As a reference, the amount of Sir3p was determined at the euchromatic WHI3 gene, which has previously been shown to bind the Sir3p protein (25Lieb J.D. Liu X. Botstein D. Brown P.O. Nat. Genet. 2001; 28: 327-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (555) Google Scholar). The amount of Sir3p found at WHI3 was arbitrarily ascribed a value of 1 (Fig. 2A). As expected, Sir3p was concentrated at heterochromatic sites relative to the amount at WHI3 or another euchromatic gene, MPP10 (Fig. 2A). The comparative analysis of a WT strain and an isogenic set1C1068A mutant (Fig. 2B) revealed a clear reduction in the amount of Sir3p bound to chromatin, which decreased 20–45% depending on the heterochromatic site analyzed. However, at one heterochromatic site, the HMR locus, a reduction was not observed. This was consistent with our finding that silencing at HMR does not depend on Set1p (Fig. 1A). Furthermore, the amounts of Sir3p bound to the HML site and to the TEL07L::URA3 maker were also reduced (30–50%) in an H3 K4R mutant with respect to the isogenic WT strain (Fig. 2, C and D). In contrast, no difference in the binding of Sir3p at the HMR site was observed. It is noteworthy that the binding of Sir3p to heterochromatic sites is more severely affected in the set1C1068A than in the H3 K4R mutant (Fig. 2, compare B with D), despite the fact that the H3 K4R mutation abolishes telomeric silencing (data not shown). This may be because the Set1p complex is non-functional in the set1C1068A mutant compared with the H3 K4R mutant, suggesting that in the set1C1068A strain other members of the complex may contribute to Sir3p redistribution. Alternatively, H3 harboring the K4R mutation may not bind Sir3p as well as unmethylated H3, though this binding is still better than to methylated H3 Lys-4. This would result in a milder titration of Sir3p from heterochromatic areas in the H3 K4R mutant than the set1C1068A. The decrease in the amount of Sir3p bound to TEL06R concurs with an increase of Sir3p on a subtelomeric gene located 5 kb apart (Fig. 2B, YFR055w). Also PHO11, a classic subtelomeric gene located 3.5 kb from the telomeric end of chromosome I, shows a clear increase in Sir3p upon mutation of SET1. This suggests that the lack of H3 Lys-4 methylation allows Sir3p to spread out of the heterochromatic regions. A significant increase in the amount of Sir3p at scattered euchromatic loci (for instance MPP10 (Fig. 2B) and WHI3 (data not shown)) was not observed, possibly reflecting the limiting amount of Sir3p in the cell. The Effect of Set1p in Silencing Is Not Because of Changes in Acetylation or H3 Lys-79 Methylation—One possibility was that the effect of set1C1068A in Sir3p occupancy may have resulted from changes in H3 and/or H4 acetylation, which in turn could have affected the interaction of Sir3p with histones at heterochromatic sites. To rule out this possibility, ChIP was performed with antibodies specific for acetylated H4 (Pan anti-acetylated H4) and acetylated H3 Lys-9 and Lys-14. The levels of H3 and H4 acetylation at euchromatic (hyperacetylated) and heterochromatic (hypoacetylated) sites were comparable in WT and the set1C1068A mutant (Fig. 2, E and F). Hence, the effect of Set1p in silencing does not seem to be mediated by histone acetylation. Whether set1C1068A could affect the amount of Dot1p in the cell (and therefore cause hypomethylation of H3 Lys-79) was then checked. Neither the amount of Dot1p (as detected by Western blot) nor the global genome levels of H3 Lys-79 methylation were affected by the set1C1068A mutation (data not shown). In addition, it has been reported that a dot1 set1 double knock-out strain shows a synergism occupying Sir2p at heterochromatin with respect to the single deleted strains supporting individual roles for Set1p and Dot1p in the maintenance of silencing (20Ng H.H. Dole S. Struhl K. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 33625-33628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar). We conclude that the role of Set1p in silencing is mainly linked to the H3 Lys-4 methyltransferase activity of Set1p. Mutation of SET1 Affects the in Vivo Sir3p Localization— Sir3p localization in the cell gives rise to a very characteristic pattern of perinuclear foci. These foci represent an accumulation of Sir3p at the telomeres of chromosomes (26Palladino F. Laroche T. Gilson E. Axelrod A. Pillus L. Gasser S.M. Cell. 1993; 75: 543-555Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (342) Google Scholar). Mutations in several genes that affect silencing alter the intracellular distribution of Sir3p (27Laroche T. Martin S.G. Gotta M. Gorham H.C. Pryde F.E. Louis E.J. Gasser S.M. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 653-656Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because a decrease in the binding of Sir3p was observed at telomeres of chromosomes VII and VI in the set1C1068A strain, we analyzed the distribution of a functional GFP-Sir3 protein in WT versus the set1C1068A mutant. Fig. 3A shows that the clear perinuclear Sir3p foci, observed in a WT strain, is replaced by a more dispersed localization that often appears to fill the nucleus. Thus, in agreement with our ChIP data, the set1C1068A mutation affects the intracellular distribution of Sir3p in vivo. Overexpression of Sir3p Rescues the Silencing Defects on set1C1068A Strains—It was hypothesized that the silencing defect observed in the set1C1068A mutant could be suppressed by overexpression of Sir3p. To test this hypothesis, the SIR3 open reading frame was cloned under the control of the galactose-induced GAL1/10 promoter, and the protein from a 2-micron plasmid was expressed. As shown in Fig. 3B, the set1C1068A strain is defective in silencing at the telomere VII when grown on glucose-containing plates (non-overexpression of Sir3p). However, the silencing defect is almost completely rescued when the same strain is supplemented with a mixture of galactose and raffinose as the carbon source (Sir3p overexpression). This supports a model for H3 Lys-4 methylation maintaining silencing by concentrating the Sir proteins at heterochromatic sites. Lys-4 Methylation Abrogates Binding of Recombinant Sir3 to the Amino-terminal Tail of H3 in Vitro—It has been shown that the COOH terminus of Sir3p directly binds to the first 20 or so NH2-terminal amino acids of histone H3 (4Hecht A. Laroche T. Strahl-Bolsinger S. Gasser S.M. Grunstein M. Cell. 1995; 80: 583-592Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (697) Google Scholar, 5Hecht A. Strahl-Bolsinger S. Grunstein M. Nature. 1996; 383: 92-96Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar). Thus, one mechanism by which H3 Lys-4 methylation could occlude Sir3 from euchromatin but allow binding to heterochromatin would be by direct disruption of Sir3p binding to histone H3 tails. Surface plasmon resonance was used to determine whether methylation of H3 Lys-4 affects binding of Sir3p to H3 tails. The COOH terminus of Sir3p (amino acids 510–970) bound with a higher affinity to unmodified H3 tail than to peptides trimethylated at Lys-4 (Fig. 3C). This interaction appears to be stable because bound Sir3p dissociates slowly (Fig. 3D). Thus, methylation at H3 Lys-4 inhibits Sir3p binding, which is consistent with our observations that the in vivo localization of Sir3p is disrupted when H3 Lys-4 methylation is lost. Several laboratories have reported that mutations of the H3 Lys-4 methyltransferase Set1p affect silencing at different heterochromatic locations (14Briggs S.D. Bryk M. Strahl B.D. Cheung W.L. Davie J.K. Dent S.Y. Winston F. Allis C.D. Genes Dev. 2001; 15: 3286-3295Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar, 17Nislow C. Ray E. Pillus L. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 2421-2436Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar, 18Krogan N.J. Dover J. Khorrami S. Greenblatt J.F. Schneider J. Johnston M. Shilatifard A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 10753-10755Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar). The molecular basis underlying these observations remained elusive. Here it is shown that yeast lacking methylation of H3 Lys-4 displays defects in silencing at several heterochromatic sites by decreasing the amount of the silent information regulator protein Sir3p at these heterochromatic positions. Concurrently, an increase in the amount of Sir3p at adjacent subtelomeric loci is observed, which suggests that Sir3p spreads outside of the heterochromatic locations. The direct connection between Sir3p-induced silencing and H3 Lys-4 methylation comes from two experiments. First, the silencing defect observed in the catalytically inactive Set1p enzyme can be reversed by overexpression of Sir3p. Second, H3 Lys-4 methylation is shown to prevent the direct association of Sir3p with histone H3 tails. In addition to our data on Sir3p, it has been reported that there is a mild but significant decrease in the amount of Sir2p at telomeres in H3 Lys-4 methyltransferase-deficient strains (20Ng H.H. Dole S. Struhl K. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 33625-33628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar). This effect is synergistic with a lack of H3 Lys-79 methylation with respect to the amount of Sir2p bound to telomeres. A stronger defect was observed in the association of Sir3p with heterochromatin in the set1C1068A mutant than that observed for Sir2p in the strain deleted for SET1 (20Ng H.H. Dole S. Struhl K. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 33625-33628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar). This variability could reflect differences in the affinity of Sir3p and Sir4p (which recruits Sir2p to heterochromatin) for methylated H3 Lys-4, the existence of additional interactions between Sir4p and heterochromatin, or even differences due to the presence of a non-functional methyltransferase complex in the cell (set1C1068A) versus the lack of the complex, as occurs in the SET1 knock-out strain. In any case, these results strongly suggest that the Sir proteins display a higher affinity for non-methylated histones versus highly methylated histones, as is the case for non-acetylated versus acetylated histones (5Hecht A. Strahl-Bolsinger S. Grunstein M. Nature. 1996; 383: 92-96Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar, 6Carmen A.A. Milne L. Grunstein M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 4778-4781Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar). Accordingly, we observed a loss of interaction between H3 Lys-4-methylated amino-terminal tails and recombinant Sir3p in vitro. Thus, the presence of highly modified (acetylated or methylated) histones in euchromatic areas may prevent silencing factors from spreading out of heterochromatic sites. This could be a substitute mechanism to maintain silent domains of chromatin in organisms like S. cerevisiae, which lack modifications more specific to heterochromatin such as H3 Lys-9 methylation and DNA methylation. Gottschling and F. van Leeuwen for the monoclonal anti-Sir3 antibody and for providing several yeast strains. We are grateful to S. Dent Roth for providing the WZY42 F12 and the WZY42 F12 H3 Lys-4R strains.

Leukotrienes (LTs) are lipid messengers generated by leukocytes that drive inflammation and modulate neighboring cell function. The synthesis of LTs from arachidonic acid is initiated by the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO). We report for the first time that LT synthesis is inhibited by the direct action of protein kinase A (PKA) on 5-LO. The catalytic subunit of PKA directly phosphorylated 5-LO in vivo and in vitro and inhibited activity in intact cells and in vitro. Mutation of Ser-523 on human 5-LO prevented phosphorylation by PKA and restored LT synthesis. Treatment with PKA activators inhibited LTB4 synthesis in 3T3 cells expressing wild type 5-LO but not in cells expressing the S523A mutant of 5-LO. The mechanism of inhibition of LTB4 synthesis did not involve either reduced membrane association of activated 5-LO or redistribution of 5-LO from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. Instead, PKA phosphorylation of recombinant 5-LO inhibited in vitro activity, as did co-transfection of cells with 5-LO plus the catalytic subunit of PKA. Also, substitution of Ser-523 with glutamic acid, mimicking phosphorylation, resulted in the total loss of 5-LO activity. These results indicate that PKA phosphorylates 5-LO on Ser-523, which inhibits the catalytic activity of 5-LO and reduces cellular LT generation. Thus, PKA activation, as can occur in response to adenosine, prostaglandin E2, β-adrenergic agonists, and other mediators, is a means of directly reducing 5-LO activity and LT synthesis that may be important in limiting inflammation and maintaining homeostasis. Leukotrienes (LTs) are lipid messengers generated by leukocytes that drive inflammation and modulate neighboring cell function. The synthesis of LTs from arachidonic acid is initiated by the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO). We report for the first time that LT synthesis is inhibited by the direct action of protein kinase A (PKA) on 5-LO. The catalytic subunit of PKA directly phosphorylated 5-LO in vivo and in vitro and inhibited activity in intact cells and in vitro. Mutation of Ser-523 on human 5-LO prevented phosphorylation by PKA and restored LT synthesis. Treatment with PKA activators inhibited LTB4 synthesis in 3T3 cells expressing wild type 5-LO but not in cells expressing the S523A mutant of 5-LO. The mechanism of inhibition of LTB4 synthesis did not involve either reduced membrane association of activated 5-LO or redistribution of 5-LO from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. Instead, PKA phosphorylation of recombinant 5-LO inhibited in vitro activity, as did co-transfection of cells with 5-LO plus the catalytic subunit of PKA. Also, substitution of Ser-523 with glutamic acid, mimicking phosphorylation, resulted in the total loss of 5-LO activity. These results indicate that PKA phosphorylates 5-LO on Ser-523, which inhibits the catalytic activity of 5-LO and reduces cellular LT generation. Thus, PKA activation, as can occur in response to adenosine, prostaglandin E2, β-adrenergic agonists, and other mediators, is a means of directly reducing 5-LO activity and LT synthesis that may be important in limiting inflammation and maintaining homeostasis. Leukotrienes (LTs) 1The abbreviations used are: LT, leukotriene; AA, arachidonic acid; Cα, protein kinase A catalytic subunit α; CREB, cAMP response element-binding protein; LO, lipoxygenase; FLAP, 5-LO-activating protein; GFP, green fluorescent protein; EGFP, enhanced GFP; PKA, protein kinase A; MAP, mitogen-activated protein; IBMX, 3-isobutyl-1-methylxanthine; PL, phospholipase; cPLA2, cytosolic PLA2; 5-HETE, 5-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid; 5-HPETE, 5-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid; GST, glutathione S-transferase; WT, wild type; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; ELISA, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. are intercellular messengers that are secreted by leukocytes and modulate the actions of neighboring cells (reviewed in Ref. 1Funk C.D. Science. 2001; 294: 1871-1875Crossref PubMed Scopus (3050) Google Scholar). For example, LTB4 potently attracts and activates leukocytes and in this way plays an important role in the normal inflammatory response. Indeed, the underproduction of leukotrienes results in impaired host defense, manifested as susceptibility to infection (2Bailie M.B. Standiford T.J. Laichalk L.L. Coffey M.J. Strieter R. Peters-Golden M. J. Immunol. 1996; 157: 5221-5224PubMed Google Scholar). However, the overproduction of LTB4 and cysteinyl LTs contributes to several diseases, most notably chronic inflammatory diseases, including asthma (3Drazen J.M. Lilly C.M. Sperling R. Rubin P. Israel E. Adv. Prostaglandin Thromboxane Leukotriene Res. 1994; 22: 251-262PubMed Google Scholar), fibrosis (4Wilborn J. Bailie M. Coffey M. Burdick M. Strieter R. Peters-Golden M. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 97: 1827-1836Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar), and atherosclerosis (5Dwyer J.H. Allayee H. Dwyer K.M. Fan J. Wu H. Mar R. Lusis A.J. Mehrabian M. N. Engl. J. Med. 2004; 350: 29-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (554) Google Scholar, 6, Deleted in proofGoogle Scholar). Thus, processes that affect the capacity of leukocytes to synthesize and secrete leukotrienes are of clinical importance. The enzyme 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO), in concert with the 5-LO-activating protein (FLAP), initiates LT synthesis from arachidonic acid (AA), catalyzing its hydroperoxidation and dehydration to produce LTA4. This intermediate can then be converted by LTA4 hydrolase to give LTB4 or by LTC4 synthase to produce LTC4. Also important in LT generation is the source of the substrate, AA. This fatty acid may be derived endogenously, released from membrane phospholipids by phospholipases (PLs), including the group IV cytosolic PLA2 (cPLA2) (7Bonventre J.V. Huang Z. Taheri M.R. O'Leary E. Li E. Moskowitz M.A. Sapirstein A. Nature. 1997; 390: 622-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (760) Google Scholar). Alternatively, AA may be exogenously derived, released from membrane phospholipids of neighboring cells by various PLA2s. It was first demonstrated in 1970 that cAMP can inhibit the release of cysteinyl LTs, known then as slow reacting substance of anaphylaxis (8Kooman W.J. Orange R.P. Austen K.F. J. Immunol. 1970; 105: 1096-1102PubMed Google Scholar). cAMP is formed from ATP by the action of adenylyl cyclase, an integral membrane protein that is activated by Gsα-protein-coupled receptors following ligand binding. Elevated cAMP activates protein kinase A (PKA) by binding to its two inhibitory subunits, causing the release and activation of the catalytic PKA subunits. Specific phosphodiesterases hydrolyze cAMP to AMP to limit signaling through this pathway. Since the seminal finding in 1970, subsequent studies have shown that LT synthesis is inhibited by ligands that activate Gsα-protein-coupled receptors (9Ham E.A. Soderman D.D. Zanetti M.E. Dougherty H.W. McCauley E. Kuehl Jr., F.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 4349-4353Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar, 10Krump E. Picard S. Mancini J. Borgeat P. J. Exp. Borgeat P. Am. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 2000; 161: S88-S94Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar), by direct activation of adenylyl cyclase (12Marone G. Columbo M. Triggiani M. Cirillo R. Although it is clear that PKA activation inhibits LT synthesis, our understanding of the mechanism remains incomplete. Activation of PKA can lead to phosphorylation of cPLA2 (19Meliton A.Y. Munoz N.M. Liu J. Lambertino A.T. Boetticher E. Myo S. Myou S. Zhu X. Johnson M. Leff A.R. J. Allergy Clin. Alternatively, activation of PKA can be without effect (24Strokin M. Sergeeva M. Reiser G. Br. J. Pharmacol. 2003; 139: 1014-1022Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar) or can increase (25Sheu J.N. Baum M. Harkins E.W. Quigley R. Kidney Int. 1997; 52: 71-79Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar) the release of AA in other circumstances, perhaps because AA may be released by PLA2s other than cPLA2. There are, to our knowledge, no reports of PKA inhibition of either the 12-LO or the 15-LO pathways, suggesting that these pathways are able to obtain AA during PKA activation and that these LOs are not inhibited by PKA. The production of LTB4 (10Krump E. Picard S. Mancini J. Borgeat P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 186: 1401-1406Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 17Surette M.E. Krump E. Picard S. Borgeat P. Mol.
